text: :slightly_smiling_face:

How many bots are you guys running? I'm still 'old fashioned' and manually fire off bots via SSH. Source code is on GitHub, so it's a simple 2 command pull and deploy. At what point did you decide to start using containers/automation?

elements.text: How many bots are you guys running? I'm still 'old fashioned' and manually fire off bots via SSH. Source code is on GitHub, so it's a simple 2 command pull and deploy. At what point did you decide to start using containers/automation?

text: Once running, bots are left untouched for months, so I'm intrigued at what point automated deployment is necessary?

elements.text: Once running, bots are left untouched for months, so I'm intrigued at what point automated deployment is necessary?

text: I have my own development framework, but I run one single application to automate bets. It has a GUI, dynamic config, and once stable, can also run for months. I deploy manually because I can customise how I deploy the binaries. Works well for a single developer

elements.text: I have my own development framework, but I run one single application to automate bets. It has a GUI, dynamic config, and once stable, can also run for months. I deploy manually because I can customise how I deploy the binaries. Works well for a single developer

text: I also run from one server, which has a suite of other applications, a database, runs a web server, etc. I take snapshots of the server as backup and if I need another one

elements.text: I also run from one server, which has a suite of other applications, a database, runs a web server, etc. I take snapshots of the server as backup and if I need another one
